BE11:15am

Melrose has once again stepped up the level of aggression in its bid for GKN. Its use of language like “Final offer” is deliberate, as is the protestation that it will not extend the deadline for acceptance again without GKN’s consent. There was no real need to go this early with moves such as these, Melrose in theory had until 19th March to make any tactical shifts in its Offer Document. In doing so today, Melrose is showing us that it is trying to seize on the lack of momentum perceived in GKN’s Dana defence – their read would appear to suggest that they think GKN has nothing left to announce now. In theory GKN still has today to give us new information. One should still expect to see Melrose waive down the minimum acceptance level required (currently 90%), potentially as low as 50%, ahead of this deadline – but GKN is now well and truly under the cosh. A 10% improvement to the transaction terms isn’t to be sniffed at and Melrose can clearly now smell blood. It will be interesting to see whether GKN cede to allow Melrose to slow the Offer timetable (allowing them to get CFIUS approval in the Offer timeline). In theory, GKN were always likely to do this to give themselves longer to defend the company. With rumours still around about potential Aerospace transactions, this is likely to remain the case – but if Dana is all GKN has got they may prefer to force Melrose to close the deal without CFIUS approval (if CFIUS still hasn’t approved within the Offer timetable). Either way we are moving into the end-game here, where GKN shareholders have to decide.

Miss Piggy "unproductive competitiveness"

Assuming Project Boost is largely successful, our DCF valuation is 493p. Our SOTP
valuation for GKN is 525p. We suppose the choices are now whether Dana can match
Melrose, whether GKN will be a better seller of Powder Metallurgy and whether Melrose
can better GKN's execution in Aerospace. GKN shareholders have choices to make, but do
now have plenty numbers to work with.

BE11:30am

With likely launch in 2020, timing could be similar to Sandoz (recent CRL), with Mylan potentially launching in mid-2018 barring any further delays. In our base case described in The Pipeline and Generic Advair Come for Free, (Sep-17), we had assumed a 2019 launch for generic Advair and $300m in peak sales which we valued at 17p per share. With the existing business valued at 97p and our estimate of generic Advair valued at 17p, we continue to believe market expectations for the rest of the pipeline are too pessimistic. 2018 data points should increase market perception of pipeline value, particularly with Phase 3 data for VR475 in 2H18. We expect the continued roll-out of VR876 by Bayer to establish the commercial viability of the FAVORITE technology, but we ccept that it may take time for the market to give meaningful value to the pipeline.

BE11:30am

And Panmure.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

We believe the certainty given by today’s announcement is positive for Vectura, removing debate over timing. However, in our view the current share price does not contain any value for the drug or others in the pipeline, including only the currently marketed products, making the stock good value at the current price. Vectura announced a revised strategy in January to focus on respiratory generics and the partnered programs, reducing investment in the earlier stage products. In our view, the new model has significantly reduced risk and we believe once investors become comfortable with the revised approach, potentially after some new deals we expect a rerating of the shares.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

German utilities are reshaping themselves yet again. Less than two years after the splits of E.ON and RWE, RWE’s subsidiary Innogy is about to be merged, by way of an asset swap, into E.ON, with renewables moving over to RWE. That would leave E.ON with networks and retail (and its majority-owned nuclear plants), and RWE with conventional and renewable energy assets. The transaction is likely to be carried out in several stages. What we know today appears favourable for RWE, which gets a new perspective with an enlarged global renewables business and a high price for Innogy (EUR40 vs. our EUR35 TP); good for Innogy shareholders, who get a high price (and should accept); and more mixed for E.ON, as it pays a high price (EUR40), doubles up in networks, whose valuations are probably at their structural peak, and in retail, which is a trouble house. However, we would expect several transactions over several stages, and E.ON appears likely to end up with only networks, in our view (retail sold or listed?). RWE is now packed; speculation about Uniper now probably needs to calm down.

Nately Sorry if posted already, but Ecclesiastical have nailed that Aviva prefs thing from last week:"Ecclesiastical notes Aviva's governance statement that "as one of the biggest companies in our sector, we aim to make our industry work better for everyone. That starts with us building trust with our customers, investors and shareholders by running our business honestly and transparently." Ecclesiastical trusts that Aviva will follow the principles set out in that statement when considering whether to pursue this course of action. "

In summary, we see the proposed transaction as being potentially more positive for E.ON than RWE, as we need to assume a reasonably generous valuation of the non-renewable assets involved in the deal and, more importantly, a low leverage for the renewables assets that will be transferred to RWE, to make the transaction neutral to RWE. For E.ON, the transaction looks value neutral before including synergies, which we estimate could amount to €200-400m

Deutsche. Competing with Deliveroo's gonna be expensive, is the gist.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Just Eat is expanding into food takeaway delivery, an already crowded market, versus the company's existing position as an order aggregation platform. In the regions where Just Eat will initially expand delivery services, Australia and the UK, UberEats and Deliveroo are already well established. Investors are mistaken to assume that Just Eat's move into delivery in 2018 will follow the same pattern as GrubHub in 2015, when the stock initially underperformed and then re-rated. When GrubHub expanded into delivery, they had an early mover advantage in the US as UberEats had only just launched. More recent example from Takeaway.com shows that it's hard to make delivery profitable; in 2017 the Netherlands margin came down by 5pp while delivered orders rose just 1pp.

BE11:56am

We think Just Eat's investment plan makes strategic sense, but with substantial implementation risks, additional costs and an uncertain return. Management hasn't committed to a particular level of spend beyond 2018 but we think investment will continue at a rapid rate. We thought it was likely the new CEO was going to announce an expansion into delivery and as a result we downgraded to Hold, from Buy, in November 2017 (see our report "Just full" Nov 2017 ). But the scale of investment and the urgency to face competition were much greater than we expected - as a result we downgrade to Sell.

BE11:59am

Oh, hang on, that Canaccord note's a downgrade. That's curious.

BE12:00pm

We downgrade to a Hold rating after the recent share price increase with now more
limited upside to our price target. The recent interim results were all broadly in line
with expectations and recent guidance, however, the results were overshadowed by the
somewhat surprising news that the group intended to raise equity of £150m. While the
balance sheet remains relatively sound, recent losses on historic construction contracts,
exacerbated by the liquidation of Carillion, prompted management to strengthen the
balance sheet further, to avoid having to constrain investment in attractive growth
opportunities it sees across its business. We left our underlying forecasts unchanged
and did not factor in the impact of the proposed, and fully underwritten, equity raise
on the share count; we await the exact terms. For now we downgrade to a Hold and
await further details on the rights issue. Assuming a successful equity raise, the balance
sheet would strengthen and the investment case is then back to the long-term growth
objectives, particularly in respect of its housing businesses and ensuring that legacy
construction contracts are worked through with new contracts performing better as risk
is better managed.
